transcript:
Therapist: You mentioned earlier that you'd like to work on challenging your core belief of not being good enough. Let's explore that further. Can you share a recent situation where this belief was triggered?

Patient: Sure. Last week, I had a group project due for one of my classes. I was struggling with my fibromyalgia and couldn't contribute as much as I wanted to. My group mates were understanding, but I kept thinking that I was letting them down and that I wasn't good enough.

Therapist: Thank you for sharing that, Mariana. Let's use the Downward Arrow technique to uncover the underlying beliefs connected to this situation. If you believed that you were letting your group mates down and weren't good enough, what would that mean about you?

Patient: It would mean that I'm not capable of handling my responsibilities and that I'm a burden on others.

Therapist: And if that were true, what would that mean about you?

Patient: It would mean that I'm not worthy of love and respect.

Therapist: That's a powerful insight, Mariana. We've identified a core belief that "I'm not worthy of love and respect" and an intermediate belief that "If I don't handle my responsibilities perfectly, I'm a burden on others." Let's work on reframing these beliefs. What evidence do you have that challenges these beliefs?

Patient: Well, my group mates were understanding and didn't seem to think I was a burden. And my family has always been supportive, even when I'm struggling.

Therapist: That's great evidence against your negative beliefs. Let's generate some alternative thoughts based on this evidence. What's a more balanced way to view this situation?

Patient: I guess I could say that even though I wasn't able to contribute as much as I wanted to, my group mates understood, and we still completed the project. And my worth isn't defined by how much I can do, but by who I am as a person.

Therapist: That's a much more compassionate and realistic way to view the situation, Mariana. As we continue to challenge these negative beliefs, it will become easier to recognize and reframe them in the moment. Remember, our thoughts, feelings, and behaviors are all interconnected. By changing our thoughts, we can influence our emotions and actions.

Patient: That makes sense. I'm starting to see how these negative beliefs have been affecting me, and I'm ready to work on changing them.

Therapist: That's great, Mariana. I'm here to support you every step of the way. Another technique we can use to reinforce your new, more adaptive beliefs is the Positive Data Log. This involves actively looking for and recording evidence that supports your new beliefs. For example, you could write down instances where you felt loved and respected, even when you weren't able to meet your own high standards.

Patient: I like that idea. It will help me focus on the positive rather than getting stuck in negative thought patterns.

Therapist: Exactly. As you continue to gather evidence for your new beliefs, they will become stronger and more automatic. It's a process, but with practice, it will get easier.

Patient: Thank you, Nova. I feel like I'm starting to make progress, and I'm grateful for your support.

Therapist: You're welcome, Mariana. Remember, change takes time, and it's okay to have setbacks along the way. What matters is that you keep trying and don't give up on yourself. You're doing great work, and I'm confident that you'll continue to make progress.
